query: My husband has advanced dementia and I'm his full-time carer in liverpool. I'm exhausted and need support. What are my options?

This will look at what support they need in their role as carer and how we can help. Find out more about carer's assessments and how to refer . Adults with eligible support needs If an adult is eligible for support from adult social care a support enquiry will help us decide what the next steps should be. You can submit a support enquiry online below. You can only refer adults within the Liverpool local authority area. If they live outside the Liverpool area, please refer to the appropriate local authority. Before you start a support enquiry If you don’t already have an online social care portal account, you must register first before submitting a referral. As part of the registration process, we will send a security authentication code to your email address – we will do this each time you sign in

Support for carers Caring for someone can be demanding and isolating, which is why it is so important to get support – whether from other carers or organisations. Liverpool Carers Centre The carers centre provides information, advice and support to unpaid carers. We offer carers activities and training and the opportunity to meet other carers in similar situations. If you would like to find out more about the support we offer or register as a carer, please contact us at: Local Solutions, Liverpool Carers Centre 99 Edge Lane Liverpool L7 2PE Telephone: 0151 705 2307. Email: carerscentre@localsolutions.org.uk . Visit the Local Solutions website . Carers UK An online resource for unpaid carers with expert information, advice and support, and also campaign to make life better for carers. Visit the Carers UK website

. There is a range of advice, support and activities in the Liverpool City Region that are open to everyone. There may be something you can access that will mean you do not need a formal assessment or support from adult social care. How to request an assessment If you or someone you know is eligible under the Care Act you can complete an assessment online . This will ask you some questions to find out a bit more about your circumstances. What happens next? Depending on your circumstances, we may decide to carry out a full care needs assessment. This gives us an opportunity to ask what will help you to improve your wellbeing and live how you want to live. We will ask what's important to you and make sure the plan is tailored to help achieve your specified outcomes. If we don't feel a full care needs assessment is appropriate we will discuss other options with you

Support from an advocate When making decisions about your care you may want someone to speak up for you if you do not have a family member or friend to support you. If you need support you can use an advocate - someone who offers independent support. Advocates can be present when you attend meetings or assessments. They can also speak to us on your behalf. An advocate can support you if you find it hard to understand or remember information, or if you can't express your wishes or feelings. They can also help you to: make decisions about your care get the right help and support challenge the council if you do not agree with a decision. Who can get an advocate? If you are receiving support from us and do not have a family member or friend who can help, you can get support from an advocate. How to get an advocate Our advocates are provided by the Liverpool Advocacy Hub

. Live Well Directory You can also search for services for yourself and for the person for whom you care on the Live Well Directory . The directory lets you search services near you, by your postcode or by types of activity across Liverpool and the wider city region. Young carers If you are aged 25 and under and look after a family member due to a long term illness or disability, the Barnardo's Action with Young Carers Service can help you. See our 'Young carers' page for more information and how to access the service . Short breaks Short breaks give looked after people and their carers time away from their usual routine. Breaks can be different for everyone, they depend on what would be helpful to you in your caring role. See our 'Short breaks' page for more information and how to access the service. Housing and care home enquiries Choose a topic I need to find a care home - what do I do? You can find all residential homes in Liverpool via the Care Quality Commission website . You can search for residential homes according to your needs, by location or whether you require nursing care. You can also view our housing and care homes section for more information. My home doesn't meet my needs due to mobility problems An occupational therapy (OT) assessment will look at what aids or adaptations will help you to live more independently at home, and other options if more major works are required. Find out how what help is available and how to access the OT service . How do I apply for sheltered housing? You must join the Property Pool Plus housing register before you can apply for sheltered accommodation. See 'sheltered housing' for more information and how to register . I'm homeless - how do I get support? The Housing Options service may be able to help if you are legally homeless

Adult learning We deliver accessible, high quality, adult learning opportunities for the people of Liverpool. You may also qualify for free childcare. If you find yourself in crisis you can apply for support to get food and necessities for you and your 
family including gas and electric vouchers (urgent needs) and furniture and household essentials

You may need support in an emergency or crisis such as a fire or flood, or you have had to move

As a full-time carer for your husband with advanced dementia in Liverpool, you have several support options available to help alleviate your exhaustion.

**Carer's Assessment and Support:**
- You can refer yourself for a **carer's assessment** through Liverpool City Council. This assessment will evaluate your needs as a carer and determine what support can be provided to you. More information and referrals can be made through the Liverpool City Council's website [here](https://www.liverpool.gov.uk/adult-social-care/professional-referrals/request-support-for-an-adult/).

**Liverpool Carers Centre:**
- The **Liverpool Carers Centre** offers information, advice, and support specifically for unpaid carers. They provide activities, training, and opportunities to meet other carers in similar situations. You can contact them at Local Solutions, 99 Edge Lane, Liverpool L7 2PE, by phone at **0151 705 2307**, or via email at **carerscentre@localsolutions.org.uk**.

**Short Breaks:**
- Consider accessing **short breaks** to give yourself time away from your usual routine. These breaks are tailored to your needs and can be arranged through Liverpool City Council. More information is available on their website.

**Advocacy Support:**
- If you need someone to speak on your behalf or help you navigate care decisions, you can access support from an advocate through the **Liverpool Advocacy Hub**. Contact them at **0300 303 0629** or email **referral@liverpooladvocacyhub.org.uk**.

**Additional Resources:**
- Explore the **Live Well Directory** to find local services and support groups that might be beneficial for you and your husband. This directory allows you to search for services by postcode or type of activity.

By utilizing these resources, you can find the support you need to manage your role as a carer more effectively.
